Award.AwardTitle: How effective is effective stress? The evolution of the effective stress law through the brittle-ductile transition
Award.AbstractNarration:
Dr. Hannah Rabinowitz has been granted an NSF EAR Postdoctoral Fellowship to carry out research and education activities at Brown University. The research project focuses on carrying out deformation experiments to characterize the stress regime in the zone where large earthquakes originate. Earthquakes occur in the Earth's crust where deformation is controlled by brittle fracture and frictional sliding. This brittle portion of the crust is underlain by ductilely flowing material, and the depth to the ductile transition controls how large an earthquake can become. Describing deformation at brittle-ductile transition is essential to the understanding of the nucleation processes that initiate large, societally damaging earthquakes. For the education plan, Dr. Rabinowitz teaches at multiple levels conducting hands-on labs with elementary school children in Providence, RI; leading a seminar course at Brown University; and mentoring an undergraduate student to conduct microstructural analyses as part of a senior thesis.

This project addresses the evolution of crustal strength through the brittle-ductile transition (BDT). The combination of the mechanical and detailed microstructural analyses provides new insight into the evolution of the effective stress law through the BDT and the microstructural mechanisms that control the transition in deformation style at the base of the seismogenic zone. Deformation experiments will be conducted to characterize the BDT in the context of a changing effective stress. Experiments on quartz with water pore fluid at pressure and temperature conditions spanning the BDT will allow for the assessment of the conditions at which the effective stress law controls rock strength. Furthermore, experiments on copper with argon gas pore fluid will allow for the isolation of the mechanical effects of pore fluid pressure without the weakening that is expected in quartz in the presence of water. Both 2D and 3D microstructures will be analyzed to determine how the mechanical evolution through the BDT is related to an evolving porosity structure. 2D imaging will be accomplished using traditional techniques such as optical microscopy and scanning electron microscopy (SEM). 3D imaging will be conducted using X-ray microtomography at the University of Maryland.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Earthquakes occur in the Earth’s crust where deformation is controlled by brittle fracture and frictional sliding. This shallow brittle portion of the crust is underlain by ductilely flowing material. The depth of the transition from brittle to ductile deformation controls how large an earthquake can become and is generally represented by a sharp brittle–ductile transition (BDT). Rocks above that depth are fully brittle and can host earthquakes, while rocks below that depth cannot. However, the transition is more likely to occur over a range of depths and depend on multiple factors, including pressure, temperature, and strain rate. The presence of water can dramatically impact how these factors control rock deformation. For example, the presence of water can lead to high pore fluid pressure at the BDT, where pore volume decreases due to the onset of ductile deformation. The associated increase in pore fluid pressure can reduce the stress felt by the rocks (effective stress), which could make earthquakes more likely at the base of the seismogenic zone. Understanding the evolution of effective stress at these conditions is essential for determining the mechanisms that control earthquake nucleation and propagation near the BDT. These effects are described by the effective stress law, which expresses the extent to which pore pressure acts in opposition to the normal stress on a rock. In the shallowest crust, a fully efficient effective stress relationship is generally assumed due to the high porosity and permeability of these rocks. However, as plastic deformation mechanisms become more efficient with increasing depth and temperature, porosity is reduced to near zero. At this limit, the rock is fully ductile. The efficiency of effective stress near the BDT, where a range of seismic activity (including tremor and the nucleation of large earthquakes) occurs, is still poorly understood.

To build towards understanding these different effects, deformation experiments were conducted at Brown University to characterize the BDT in the context of a changing effective stress. Experiments were conducted on quartz with water pore fluid at pressure and temperature conditions ranging from room temperature to 700 ºC, confining pressures up to 1 GPa, and different amounts of added water. Both 2D and 3D microstructures were imaged to determine how the mechanical evolution through the BDT is related to an evolving porosity structure. 2D imaging used traditional techniques such as optical microscopy and scanning electron microscopy (SEM). 3D imaging consisted X-ray microtomography collected at Argonne National Laboratory’s Advanced Photon Source (APS) in August 2019.

In addition to data collection, some of the major outcomes of this fellowship were mentoring and outreach. I worked with a group of graduate students and postdocs from Brown University to teach elementary school students in Providence, Rhode Island about weather and climate. Additionally, I collaborated with Ph.D. students in the Rock Deformation Lab, assisting with equipment upgrades and working with them on their scientific writing, as well as helping visiting students learn how to use the deformation apparatus. Finally, I worked in the lab on some of the deformation experiments described above with a Brown University undergraduate student. This included teaching him to run the experiments and how to prepare and analyze thin sections for 2D microstructural analysis as well as taking him to APS to conduct X-ray microtomography. This work was presented as a poster at AGU 2019.
